attributes.title: Chemistry Online Learning Study
attributes.description: This is an online experimental study with random assignment examining the potential effects of writing notes for another student (vs. writing notes for self) on the learning outcome of introductory Chemistry for non-major students.
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

question10b.value:
Materials
Chemistry learning materials.  Chemistry learning materials and quiz questions were developed by one of the investigator who is an Assistant Professor in Chemistry, and a research assistant who majors in psychology and minor in Chemistry.  Quiz questions are available for download at https://osf.io/dfjc6/.  Students will be shown a video of a chemistry lecture (see here for the video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z1kucSx-Cdo)
Pre-lecture.  
Pre-test Chemistry anxiety.  Students are asked to report their level of anxiety in taking a Chemistry course and learning Chemistry.  Nine items were adapted from the Abbreviated Mathematics Anxiety Rating Scales (AMAS, Hopko, Mahadevan, Bare, & Hunt, 2003). Sample items were “thinking about an upcoming chemistry test one day before”, “watching a teacher work a chemistry equation on the blackboard”, and “taking an examination in a chemistry course”.  The scale was found to be valid and reliable (internal consistency: alpha = .90; test-retest: alpha = .85).   
Pre-test chemistry interest and anxiety.  Chemistry and science interests and career goal are measured separately using two items from the Modified Attitudes toward Science Inventory (mASI) (Weinburgh & Steele, 2000), “Chemistry/science is something which I enjoy very much” and “Chemistry/science is one of my favorite subject” and one self-constructed item on career interest, “I want to pursue a career that involves chemistry/science.”  Finally, three items are used to measure how they perceive their knowledge in chemistry, including “I can help someone learn basic chemistry”, “I enjoy discussing basic Chemistry with others.”, and “I am knowledgeable in basic Chemistry.”  We used the word “basic” because of the context of this study teaching students introductory Chemistry.  All items were rated on a 6-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 6 (strongly agree). 
Pre-lecture Chemistry assessment quiz questions. Students will be given three easy, medium and hard questions (a total of 9 questions)
Demographics.  Demographics questions, such as gender, age, race, and year in college were included in the survey. 
Post-lecture.  After viewing the lecture, students will be asked to fill out a brief survey and a post-lecture chemistry assessment quiz.  In the survey, the students will be asked, “I am interested in learning about balancing equation”.  Students will also be asked to rate the lecture, “The lectures were interesting”, and “The lectures were informative.” All items were rated on a 6-point Likert scale from 1 (strongly disagree) to 6 (strongly agree). 
Post-lecture chemistry assessment quiz questions. Students will be given another set of chemistry quiz questions, including three easy, medium and hard questions (a total of 9 questions).
Post-test chemistry Interest and Anxiety.  The same test that is given for pre-lecture is given again for the students at the end of the experiment. 
Participants are also asked to self-report how focused they are during the study.  In addition, a set of questions tapping into students’ current physical distancing/shelter-at-home practice, and emotion and social support experienced during COVID-19 are included.  Students are also asked to report whether they see themselves as an introvert/extrovert.

Students who sign up will then be given a link to work on the study on their own computer.

question6b.value:
The minimum sample size is computed using Gpower using t-test for Linear multiple regression: Fixed model, single regression coefficients using criteria of effect size = .15, alpha = .05, power = .95, and number of predictors = 3, resulting in the desired sample size of 89.

Another test was computed using repeated measure ANOVA with within-between interaction.  The criteria of small effect size (.25), alpha = .05, power = .95, number of groups = 4, number of measurements = 2, and a correlation of .5 between repeated measures, resulting in the desired sample size of 76. 

Both tests are showing similar number of sample requirements. To account for attrition, 100 participants will be collected for this study.

question7b.value: Data collection will be terminated when desired sample size is reached, or when the data collection semester ends (SP 2020).

b) NA

d) outliers will be detected and if present, both a model with and a model without outlier will be analyzed.

question1a.value:
1. All participants, regardless of conditions (experimental vs. control), should have an improved Chemistry Quiz scores after viewing the lecture video.  In other words, we are hypothesizing that there is a within-subject effect between pre- and post-test scores.   
      a. However, we are hypothesizing that the score change will be predicted positively by how focused/attentive they are (self-report focus/attentiveness), interest in Chemistry, and perceived helpfulness of the video lecture, and negatively by anxiety in Chemistry. 
2. Participants in the experimental condition (learning while told to help another student as a peer mentor, directed outward) will have a significantly better learning outcome (i.e. higher post-test score while controlling for pre-test score) than will participants in the control condition (learning while told to write notes for themselves, i.e. directed inward).  
3. The experimental effect (hypothesized in #2) will be moderated by participants' current state, including learning anxiety during

question2a.value:
a.	Specifically, it is hypothesized that the experimental condition has a stronger effect on students who see themselves as extroverts and are having limited social interactions because of physical distancing would than students who see themselves as introverts.  The rationale is that students who see themselves as extroverts may have a higher need to feel connected to another student than those who see themselves as less of extroverts.  Therefore, they may benefit more from the experimental manipulation (i.e. writing something for another student) than may students who see themselves as an introvert.
b.	Similarly, students who are practicing physical distancing/shelter-at-home during COVID-19 outbreak or students who experience an increased amount of learning anxiety during the COVID-19 outbreak may feel a higher need to feel connected to other students.  Therefore, it is also hypothesized that for students who reported doing more physical distancing/shelter-at-home, the relations between conditions and learning outcomes will also be stronger.

question3a.value:
A variable, perception of one's own ability in helping others will be used as a manipulation check variable.  A successful check is indicated if participants in the experimental group have a higher score than have participants in the control group.  

However, because the goal of this study is to merely understand whether writing something for self versus writing something for another student (i.e. being a note-taker for another student) results in a different learning outcome, manipulation check is not necessary for interpreting results.

question1c.value: All score scores (interest in chemistry, chemistry anxiety) are computed using a mean score.  Quiz scores are computed by adding all correct answers (1 point for 1 correct answer). Therefore, students can earn from 0 to 9 points on both pre- and post-test. Single-item variable (e.g., perceived extroversion/introversion, time spent during physical distancing/shelter at home) will be used as a raw score and will be treated as continuous variable.

question2c.value:
a.	Hypothesis 1: Pair sample t-test for simple within-subject difference pre- and post-test.  Four linear mixed models estimating a random slope for participants will be used to predict learning outcome from each of the main effects of self-report focus/attentiveness, interest in Chemistry, perceived helpfulness of the video lecture, and chemistry anxiety, and the interaction effect between time (pre vs. post) and the predicting variables. 
b.	Hypothesis 2: Three separate linear mixed models estimating random slope for participants will be used to predict learning outcomes (Quiz scores, interest in Chemistry, and reduced anxiety in Chemistry) from the main effect of time (pre vs. post), main effect of condition (experimental vs. control)  and the interaction effect of time x condition.  
c.	Hypothesis 3: similar to H2 but with interaction terms added to the linear mixed model equation.

question5c.value: a p-value of .05 will be used

attributes.title: Food, Diversity, and COVID-19
attributes.description: The effects of COVID-19 and neighborhood environment on adults’ reasoning about foreign foods
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
a.	Food type (western, conventional, foreign, unconventional, vs. nonfood) is a within-subject variable
b.	Label (label vs. not labeled) is a between-subject variable
c.	Demographic variables are between-subject variables that are self-reported. 
i.	Demographic information:
1.	age in years
2.	gender (male, female, other)
3.	race or ethnicity (7 distinct racial categories and 8th category for bi- or multi-racial)
4.	highest level of education (1= 8th grade of less to 7 = graduate or professional degree)
ii.	Language exposure variables 
1.	Native language (3 categories: English, English-Other language, and Other language)
2.	Regularly hears another language (yes vs. no)
3.	We will group participants into the following categories based on the above two questions: (1) bilingual: has more than one native language; (2) exposure: has only one native language but regularly hears other languages; (3) no exposure: has only one native language and does not regularly hear other languages. 
iii.	Intergroup contact
1.	Quantity of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
2.	Pleasantness of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
3.	Quantity of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
4.	Pleasantness of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
5.	Sum the self-report ratings of the contact quantity with racial and linguistic outgroups to create a “contact quantity” composite score (range 2 to 10)
6.	Sum the self-report ratings of the contact quality with racial and linguistic outgroups to create a “contact quality” composite score (range 2 to 10)
iv.	Neighborhood demographics according to zip code
1.	Zip code
2.	Linguistic diversity in zip code:
a.	Entropy of linguistic diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different language groups accounting for proportion) that uses the number of and proportion of language groups from ACS and is calculated using the R package “entropy” (Hausser & Strimme, 2009)
3.	Racial diversity in zip code: 
a.	Entropy of racial diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different race groups accounting for proportion) that is calculated the same way as entropy of linguistic diversity but uses ACS on race instead.
4.	Sum the entropy of racial and linguistic population to create a “cultural entropy” composite score 
5.	Median income in zip code (continuous) that is extracted directly from ACS 
6.	Population density in zip code (number of people per square mile) that is extracted directly from the latest US census
7.	Education level in zip code (the proportion of people with high school diploma or above) extracted directly from ACS.
8.	Access to different cuisines: Using Yelp academic dataset (https://www.yelp.com/dataset/documentation/main), we will calculate the entropy of different cuisines (i.e., assess variety and proportion of different cuisines in zip code) and how many restaurants are in the zip code. We will sum these two metrics to create a “cuisine diversity” score. However, this dataset is only a subset and does not include information on all US zip codes. Therefore, we will use this metric only if we have more than 50 participants who are within this subset Yelp dataset zip code.
9.	Number of COVID cases in county/state level. We will extract the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases at the county/state level in the U.S. using data from NYtimes: https://github.com/nytimes/covid-19-dat

d.	Political ideology: (1= very conservative to 5= very liberal) from the Gallup (https://news.gallup.com/poll/225074/conservative-lead-ideology-down-single-digits.aspx). 
e.	Neighborhood trust (5 to 25; greater number, greater trust) sum of responses from “social cohesion and trust” scale from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). 
f.	General social trust (3 items with 2 binary answers): We will sort individuals into 3 categories: (1) high trusters: answer all 3 questions with trustful answers; (2) medium trusters: answer at least one question with trusting answer and one with non-trusting answer (mixed answers); (3) low trusters: answer all three with non-trusting answers. From Pew research center.
g.	COVID-19 effect on personal life: questions from the Pew research center that asks how COVID-19 has impacted personal life (https://www.pewresearch.org/pathways-2020/covidchg/total_us_adults/us_adults/). 
i.	The questions are divided into a general impact question, social distance, anxiety/stress, change in lifestyle, impact on health, and impact on financial situation blocks. We will group questions into these blocks and examine each block’s predictability.

question2b.value: a.	Acceptability rating: Rating of how acceptable a food item is to eat (1 = really not okay to 5 = really okay to eat)

question3b.value:
a.	Food neophobia 
1.	Food Neophobia scale (score of 10 to 70, higher meaning more neophobic)
2.	Food Neophobia scale reduced (score of 10 to 49, higher meaning more neophobic): This subscale of the food neophobia scale will not include items 4, 5, and 10, which ask specifically about ethnic foods 
b.	Dietary restrictions
i.	dietary restrictions (yes/ no)
ii.	We will compare whether individuals who respond as having dietary restrictions show different patterns than those who do. 
c.	Political ideology

question10b.value:
Method
Participants
	500 adults above the age of 18, located in the U.S., have an approval rating of 75% or above were recruited from Amazon MTurk. Must have correctly answered CAPTCHA (bot detection). 

Design & materials
Participants were randomly assigned to either the label or no label condition. Participants viewed eight items each of western food, conventional combinations, foreign food, unconventional combinations, and nonfood items presented via Qualtrics survey platform. All items had an accompanying picture, one sentence description, and a 5-point scale to indicate how okay it is to eat this item (see Figure 3 for the scale; see supplementary attachment for Qualtrics surveys). For foreign food items, their native language labels were used and for unconventional food items, novel labels were generated by taking novel words from the novel noun database (Horst & Hout, in press) and reversing the letter orders to create non-English sounding labels. See Tables 1 and 2 for the labels and descriptions. Participants completed a demographic survey after the acceptability ratings. 

Demographic information. Participants provided their age, gender, race/ethnicity, native language, regular exposure to non-English language, dietary restrictions, current zip code and highest level of education. 
Familiarity. Participants rated how familiar they were with the foreign foods, unconventional combinations, western foods, and conventional combinations on a 5-point scale (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal). 
Food neophobia. Participants completed the Food Neophobia Scale (Pliner & Hobden, 1992).
Intergroup contact. Participants completed four questions on quantity and quality of contact they have with people who speak different languages and people who are of a different race from the General Intergroup Contact Quantity and Contact Quality (Islam & Hewstone, 1993).  
Neighborhood trust. Participants completed the social cohesion and trust scale from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). 
General social trust. Participants completed three questions on general social trust from the Pew Research Center. 
COVID-19 effect on personal life. Participants completed questions from Pew Research Center’s COVID-19 effect on personal life. 

Procedure
	Adults accessed the Qualtrics survey via Amazon Mturk and received $1 for completing the survey.

question1a.value:
1.	Label x Food type interaction: We predict that participants will rate foreign foods and unconventional foods that are labeled as more okay to eat than those that are not labeled. We predict that there will be no label effects on western foods, conventional foods, and non-food items. 
2.	Diversity effect 
a.	Exposure to outgroup x label effect: We predict that the more exposure to cultural diversity (i.e., linguistic and racial diversity), the more acceptable participants find foreign and unconventional foods. This effect might be stronger in the no label condition than in the label condition. 
b.	Trust: We predict that greater level of trust (neighborhood and/or general trust) will be related to higher acceptability ratings toward foreign and unconventional foods. We will check if this effect holds when controlling for cultural diversity, education level, and other demographic variables (population density and median income). We will test whether effect of trust may be stronger in the no label condition compared to the label condition. 
3.	COVID-19 effects
a.	We hypothesize that those reporting greater instances of COVID-19 in the county/state level will show decrease in acceptability of foreign and unconventional foods. This effect might be stronger in the no label condition than in the label condition. 
b.	We hypothesize that those reporting greater negative personal life impact due to COVID-19 will show decrease in acceptability of foreign and unconventional foods. This effect might be stronger in the no label condition than in the label condition. 
c.	We will check if these effects hold when controlling for trust (general & neighborhood), cultural diversity, education level, and other demographic variables (population density and median income). 
d.	COVID-19 effects might be stronger on East Asian foreign food items than non-East Asian foreign food items.

registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question1a:
1.	Label x Food type interaction: We predict that participants will rate foreign foods and unconventional foods that are labeled as more okay to eat than those that are not labeled. We predict that there will be no label effects on western foods, conventional foods, and non-food items. 
2.	Diversity effect 
a.	Exposure to outgroup x label effect: We predict that the more exposure to cultural diversity (i.e., linguistic and racial diversity), the more acceptable participants find foreign and unconventional foods. This effect might be stronger in the no label condition than in the label condition. 
b.	Trust: We predict that greater level of trust (neighborhood and/or general trust) will be related to higher acceptability ratings toward foreign and unconventional foods. We will check if this effect holds when controlling for cultural diversity, education level, and other demographic variables (population density and median income). We will test whether effect of trust may be stronger in the no label condition compared to the label condition. 
3.	COVID-19 effects
a.	We hypothesize that those reporting greater instances of COVID-19 in the county/state level will show decrease in acceptability of foreign and unconventional foods. This effect might be stronger in the no label condition than in the label condition. 
b.	We hypothesize that those reporting greater negative personal life impact due to COVID-19 will show decrease in acceptability of foreign and unconventional foods. This effect might be stronger in the no label condition than in the label condition. 
c.	We will check if these effects hold when controlling for trust (general & neighborhood), cultural diversity, education level, and other demographic variables (population density and median income). 
d.	COVID-19 effects might be stronger on East Asian foreign food items than non-East Asian foreign food items.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a: See above for specification on interactions
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question3a: a.	Familiarity manipulation check: We predict that participants will rate western and conventional foods as more familiar (familiarity rating ranging from 1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal) than foreign and unconventional foods.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2a:
a.	Food type (western, conventional, foreign, unconventional, vs. nonfood) is a within-subject variable
b.	Label (label vs. not labeled) is a between-subject variable
c.	Demographic variables are between-subject variables that are self-reported. 
i.	Demographic information:
1.	age in years
2.	gender (male, female, other)
3.	race or ethnicity (7 distinct racial categories and 8th category for bi- or multi-racial)
4.	highest level of education (1= 8th grade of less to 7 = graduate or professional degree)
ii.	Language exposure variables 
1.	Native language (3 categories: English, English-Other language, and Other language)
2.	Regularly hears another language (yes vs. no)
3.	We will group participants into the following categories based on the above two questions: (1) bilingual: has more than one native language; (2) exposure: has only one native language but regularly hears other languages; (3) no exposure: has only one native language and does not regularly hear other languages. 
iii.	Intergroup contact
1.	Quantity of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
2.	Pleasantness of contact with different language speakers (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
3.	Quantity of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
4.	Pleasantness of contact with different race (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal)
5.	Sum the self-report ratings of the contact quantity with racial and linguistic outgroups to create a “contact quantity” composite score (range 2 to 10)
6.	Sum the self-report ratings of the contact quality with racial and linguistic outgroups to create a “contact quality” composite score (range 2 to 10)
iv.	Neighborhood demographics according to zip code
1.	Zip code
2.	Linguistic diversity in zip code:
a.	Entropy of linguistic diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different language groups accounting for proportion) that uses the number of and proportion of language groups from ACS and is calculated using the R package “entropy” (Hausser & Strimme, 2009)
3.	Racial diversity in zip code: 
a.	Entropy of racial diversity (0 to greater; greater positive number, more different race groups accounting for proportion) that is calculated the same way as entropy of linguistic diversity but uses ACS on race instead.
4.	Sum the entropy of racial and linguistic population to create a “cultural entropy” composite score 
5.	Median income in zip code (continuous) that is extracted directly from ACS 
6.	Population density in zip code (number of people per square mile) that is extracted directly from the latest US census
7.	Education level in zip code (the proportion of people with high school diploma or above) extracted directly from ACS.
8.	Access to different cuisines: Using Yelp academic dataset (https://www.yelp.com/dataset/documentation/main), we will calculate the entropy of different cuisines (i.e., assess variety and proportion of different cuisines in zip code) and how many restaurants are in the zip code. We will sum these two metrics to create a “cuisine diversity” score. However, this dataset is only a subset and does not include information on all US zip codes. Therefore, we will use this metric only if we have more than 50 participants who are within this subset Yelp dataset zip code.
9.	Number of COVID cases in county/state level. We will extract the number of confirmed COVID-19 cases at the county/state level in the U.S. using data from NYtimes: https://github.com/nytimes/covid-19-dat

d.	Political ideology: (1= very conservative to 5= very liberal) from the Gallup (https://news.gallup.com/poll/225074/conservative-lead-ideology-down-single-digits.aspx). 
e.	Neighborhood trust (5 to 25; greater number, greater trust) sum of responses from “social cohesion and trust” scale from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). 
f.	General social trust (3 items with 2 binary answers): We will sort individuals into 3 categories: (1) high trusters: answer all 3 questions with trustful answers; (2) medium trusters: answer at least one question with trusting answer and one with non-trusting answer (mixed answers); (3) low trusters: answer all three with non-trusting answers. From Pew research center.
g.	COVID-19 effect on personal life: questions from the Pew research center that asks how COVID-19 has impacted personal life (https://www.pewresearch.org/pathways-2020/covidchg/total_us_adults/us_adults/). 
i.	The questions are divided into a general impact question, social distance, anxiety/stress, change in lifestyle, impact on health, and impact on financial situation blocks. We will group questions into these blocks and examine each block’s predictability.
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question2b: a.	Acceptability rating: Rating of how acceptable a food item is to eat (1 = really not okay to 5 = really okay to eat)
registration_responses.description-methods.design.question3b:
a.	Food neophobia 
1.	Food Neophobia scale (score of 10 to 70, higher meaning more neophobic)
2.	Food Neophobia scale reduced (score of 10 to 49, higher meaning more neophobic): This subscale of the food neophobia scale will not include items 4, 5, and 10, which ask specifically about ethnic foods 
b.	Dietary restrictions
i.	dietary restrictions (yes/ no)
ii.	We will compare whether individuals who respond as having dietary restrictions show different patterns than those who do. 
c.	Political ideology
d.	Access to different ethnic cuisines
registration_responses.description-methods.procedure.question10:
Method
Participants
	500 adults above the age of 18, located in the U.S., have an approval rating of 75% or above were recruited from Amazon MTurk. Must have correctly answered CAPTCHA (bot detection). 

Design & materials
Participants were randomly assigned to either the label or no label condition. Participants viewed eight items each of western food, conventional combinations, foreign food, unconventional combinations, and nonfood items presented via Qualtrics survey platform. All items had an accompanying picture, one sentence description, and a 5-point scale to indicate how okay it is to eat this item (see Figure 3 for the scale; see supplementary attachment for Qualtrics surveys). For foreign food items, their native language labels were used and for unconventional food items, novel labels were generated by taking novel words from the novel noun database (Horst & Hout, in press) and reversing the letter orders to create non-English sounding labels. See Tables 1 and 2 for the labels and descriptions. Participants completed a demographic survey after the acceptability ratings. 

Demographic information. Participants provided their age, gender, race/ethnicity, native language, regular exposure to non-English language, dietary restrictions, current zip code and highest level of education. 
Familiarity. Participants rated how familiar they were with the foreign foods, unconventional combinations, western foods, and conventional combinations on a 5-point scale (1 = not at all to 5 = a great deal). 
Food neophobia. Participants completed the Food Neophobia Scale (Pliner & Hobden, 1992).
Intergroup contact. Participants completed four questions on quantity and quality of contact they have with people who speak different languages and people who are of a different race from the General Intergroup Contact Quantity and Contact Quality (Islam & Hewstone, 1993).  
Neighborhood trust. Participants completed the social cohesion and trust scale from Sampson, Raudenbush, and Earls (1997). 
General social trust. Participants completed three questions on general social trust from the Pew Research Center. 
COVID-19 effect on personal life. Participants completed questions from Pew Research Center’s COVID-19 effect on personal life. 

Procedure
	Adults accessed the Qualtrics survey via Amazon Mturk and received $1 for completing the survey.

attributes.title: A systematic literature review of drivers for Pacific patients’ decisions to utilise ED for low acuity conditions: a mixed methods review
attributes.description: A mixed-methods systematic literature review of drivers for Pacific patients’ decisions to utilise the Emergency Department for low acuity conditions, in order to better understand potential for exacerbating  inequity from initiatives discouraging use of the Emergency Department for low acuity conditions.

summary.value:
Researchers:
Catherine Yang [CY] , Executive Management, Counties Manukau District Health Board, 100 Hospital Road, Otahuhu, Auckland. Kate.yang@middlemore.co.nz
Vili Nosa [VN] Pacific Health, School of Population Health, Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences, University of Auckland. V.nosa@auckland.ac.nz
Vanessa Selak [VS] Epidemiology and Biostatistics, School of Population Health, Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences, University of Auckland. V.selak@auckland.ac.nz

Contributions: 
CY, VN and VS collectively contributed to conceptualisation of the protocol.  CY was the lead writer for the protocol.  VS and VN provided technical expertise and guidance on search strategy.  VN provided Pacific cultural expertise.  

Funding: CY received a stipend from Health Workforce New Zealand through the New Zealand College of Public Health Medicine to complete this research as part of specialist training.

Competing interests: None.

Title: A systematic literature review of drivers for Pacific patients’ decisions to utilise ED for low acuity conditions: a mixed methods review  

Introduction
Rationale: Presentations to Emergency Departments (ED) around New Zealand are increasing at an unprecedented and at an unsustainable rate.  In order to manage the increased presentations, District Health Boards (DHBs) have implemented various initiatives to kerb demand and redirect patients at the front door, such as Emergency Q. Emergency Q is an app (Apple and Android) which can issue free vouchers to direct low-acuity ED patients to Afterhours Urgent Care consultations during times when ED is busy, to encourage patients to go to alternative service providers for low acuity conditions.  The impact of these initiatives on vulnerable populations with health inequities has not been understood.   

Pacific peoples make up more than 7% of the New Zealand population.   By 2026, it is estimated that 10% of the population will identify with one or more Pacific ethnic groups.   Pacific peoples refer to a diverse group of ethno linguistically different people, but with shared cultural values of the importance of family, spirituality, community and respect.   In ’Ala Mo’ui, the Ministry of Health stated the long-term outcome focus for Pacific peoples for 2014-2018 was for ‘Pacific peoples [to] experience equitable health outcomes and lead independent lives.’ 

This outcome has yet to be realised.  Resources, including information on how to access public services, are not equally distributed across different groups in New Zealand.  The current healthcare system has been set up so that some groups are able to engage more easily with healthcare services and derive more benefit from it than others.   Non-Maaori, Non-Pacific people experience higher rates of health and wellbeing than Pacific people in almost every Ministry of Health indicator reported by ethnicity.4

Counties Manukau DHB has the largest combined adult-paediatric ED in Australasia.  It is also home to the greatest number of Pacific peoples of all DHBs, responsible for the health of nearly forty per cent of all Pacific peoples living in New Zealand.  

At Counties Manukau DHB, Pacific patients make up 21% of the catchment population but 34% of all ED presentations, making them the highest users of ED by prioritised ethnicity group.3 In June 2019, Emergency Q was introduced to the ED of Counties Manukau DHB to redirect low-acuity ED patients to Urgent Afterhours Centres.  

The reasons for Pacific patients use of ED for low acuity conditions is unclear, and it is also unclear whether interventions such as Emergency Q will support appropriate and equitable access to health services for Pacific peoples.   

The aim of this research is to:
+ Identify key drivers for Pacific patients’ use of ED for low acuity conditions

The objectives of this research are to: 
+ Identify key drivers for Pacific patients’ use of ED for low acuity conditions according to international literature 

This is a protocol for a mixed-methods systematic literature review on drivers for Pacific patients’ decisions to utilise ED for low acuity conditions.

Methods
The study will follow the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Protocol (PRISMA-P).  (Appendix 1) The methodology for this study will be registered on Open Science Framework, an international register of systematic reviews. 

Eligibility criteria
This review will include all studies, published between 2000 and 2020, written in the English language, which reported reasons for human patients choosing to use the emergency department for low-acuity conditions.  Low-acuity will be defined as any condition that could reasonably be seen by a General Practitioner or equivalent in the country of study, equivalent to Australasian Triage Scale scores of 4 and 5 described in Table 1.  

Table 1. Australasian Triage Scale definitions
Triage Category	Description	Maximum Clinically Appropriate Triage Time
1	Immediately life-threatening,	Immediate simultaneous triage and treatment
2	Imminently life-threatening, or important time-critical	10 minutes
3	Potentially life-threatening, potential adverse outcomes from delay > 30 min, or severe discomfort or distress	30 minutes
4	Potentially serious, or potential adverse outcomes from delay > 60 min, or significant complexity or severity, or discomfort or distress	60 minutes
5	Less urgent, or dealing with administrative issues only	120 minutes

The search will not exclude papers by the age of participants included in the studies.  

Information Sources
Search will be conducted during March 2020.  Electronic databases will be searched using pre-determined search terms for papers reporting either qualitative or quantitative outcomes published between 2009 and 2019.  Databases searched will include: Medline (Ovid), Embase (Ovid), The Cochrane Library (via Wiley Online Library), Google Scholar, ProQuest and CINAHL (Ebsco).  Journals searched will include Journal of the Polynesian Society and PINI (Pacific Islands News & Information), Contemporary Pacific Journal and Pacific Health Dialog.  In addition, reference lists will be hand searched.  
Gray literature will be searched for on the repository website nzresearch.org.nz, the Ministry of Health's Health Statistics website and the Ministry of Health Pacific Health website.  To identify any unpublished work, Pacific health and Emergency Medicine researchers known to the researchers will be contacted.

Search strategy
Combinations of key words and Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) were used on each information source listed.  The search strategy will be piloted and refined for each source (Appendix 2).  A professional healthcare librarian (DH) and specialist Pacific librarian (JMM) helped develop the search strategy. 

Study records
All references will be managed using EndNote X9 (Web of Science Group). This software will be used to discard duplicates and manage papers. Data will be collected using Microsoft Excel 2020.

Selection Process
Abstracts of identified papers will be reviewed by one researcher (CY) for appropriateness of inclusion into the literature review.  At this stage, articles will be classified as ‘for inclusion’ or ‘excluded’.  The titles and classifications of all articles will be recorded.  Full-texts will be retrieved for any papers in which there is doubt regarding inclusion and these will be read by all researchers and decided by consensus after discussion.  A selection of these abstracts will be read by the second and third researchers (VN, VS).

The full texts of all included articles will be obtained. The full articles will be read by one researcher (CY) to evaluate relevance.  The results of inclusion decisions will be discussed with second and third researchers (VS and VN).  The number of included and excluded papers at each step of the process will be shown through a PRISMA diagram. 

Data collection process and items
The following data will be collected:
a)	Title
b)	Authors
c)	Study aims
d)	Patient population, including ethnicity where available
e)	Inclusion and exclusion criteria
f)	Items required for quality assessment (MMAT) 
CY will collect this data and VS and VN will randomly and independently check a selection of studies to test intercoder agreement.

Quality assessment
Quality of methods will be assessed by one researcher (CY) using the Mixed Methods Appraisal Tool (MMAT).   Any ambiguity will be resolved by discussion with VS and VN.  Appendix 1 outlines the data collection criteria for assessing quality of included studies, with explanations of terms for consistency.

Data synthesis
Drivers for Pacific patient utilisation of Emergency Department or Emergency Room services will be synthesised and evaluated using the qualitative assessment method described by Thomas. 

Dissemination
The results of this analysis will be submitted for publication in a peer-reviewed journal.  Further, CY will present the findings of the research at Counties Manukau District Health Board’s Pacific Health Planning day, which will help inform service delivery planning for this population.

Cultural appropriateness
VN is Associate Professor of Pacific Health.  Further, this research will be supported by extensive senior involvement of Pacific academic and health service professionals who will help ensure that findings are interpreted in a culturally appropriate way that supports positive outcomes for Pacific people.

Ethics
Ethics approval will not be sought as this is a review of published literature.

The current healthcare system has been set up so that some groups are able to engage more easily with healthcare services and derive more benefit from it than others.   Non-Maaori, Non-Pacific people experience higher rates of health and wellbeing than Pacific people in almost every Ministry of Health indicator reported by ethnicity.4

Counties Manukau DHB has the largest combined adult-paediatric ED in Australasia.  It is also home to the greatest number of Pacific peoples of all DHBs, responsible for the health of nearly forty per cent of all Pacific peoples living in New Zealand.  

At Counties Manukau DHB, Pacific patients make up 21% of the catchment population but 34% of all ED presentations, making them the highest users of ED by prioritised ethnicity group.3 In June 2019, Emergency Q was introduced to the ED of Counties Manukau DHB to redirect low-acuity ED patients to Urgent Afterhours Centres.  

The reasons for Pacific patients use of ED for low acuity conditions is unclear, and it is also unclear whether interventions such as Emergency Q will support appropriate and equitable access to health services for Pacific peoples.   

The aim of this research is to:
+ Identify key drivers for Pacific patients’ use of ED for low acuity conditions

The objectives of this research are to: 
+ Identify key drivers for Pacific patients’ use of ED for low acuity conditions according to international literature 

This is a protocol for a mixed-methods systematic literature review on drivers for Pacific patients’ decisions to utilise ED for low acuity conditions.

Methods
The study will follow the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Protocol (PRISMA-P).  (Appendix 1) The methodology for this study will be registered on Open Science Framework, an international register of systematic reviews. 

Eligibility criteria
This review will include all studies, published between 2000 and 2020, written in the English language, which reported reasons for human patients choosing to use the emergency department for low-acuity conditions.  Low-acuity will be defined as any condition that could reasonably be seen by a General Practitioner or equivalent in the country of study, equivalent to Australasian Triage Scale scores of 4 and 5 described in Table 1.  

Table 1. Australasian Triage Scale definitions
Triage Category	Description	Maximum Clinically Appropriate Triage Time
1	Immediately life-threatening,	Immediate simultaneous triage and treatment
2	Imminently life-threatening, or important time-critical	10 minutes
3	Potentially life-threatening, potential adverse outcomes from delay > 30 min, or severe discomfort or distress	30 minutes
4	Potentially serious, or potential adverse outcomes from delay > 60 min, or significant complexity or severity, or discomfort or distress	60 minutes
5	Less urgent, or dealing with administrative issues only	120 minutes

The search will not exclude papers by the age of participants included in the studies.  

Information Sources
Search will be conducted during March 2020.  Electronic databases will be searched using pre-determined search terms for papers reporting either qualitative or quantitative outcomes published between 2009 and 2019.  Databases searched will include: Medline (Ovid), Embase (Ovid), The Cochrane Library (via Wiley Online Library), Google Scholar, ProQuest and CINAHL (Ebsco).  Journals searched will include Journal of the Polynesian Society and PINI (Pacific Islands News & Information), Contemporary Pacific Journal and Pacific Health Dialog.  In addition, reference lists will be hand searched.  
Gray literature will be searched for on the repository website nzresearch.org.nz, the Ministry of Health's Health Statistics website and the Ministry of Health Pacific Health website.  To identify any unpublished work, Pacific health and Emergency Medicine researchers known to the researchers will be contacted.

Search strategy
Combinations of key words and Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) were used on each information source listed.  The search strategy will be piloted and refined for each source (Appendix 2).  A professional healthcare librarian (DH) and specialist Pacific librarian (JMM) helped develop the search strategy. 

Study records
All references will be managed using EndNote X9 (Web of Science Group). This software will be used to discard duplicates and manage papers. Data will be collected using Microsoft Excel 2020.

Selection Process
Abstracts of identified papers will be reviewed by one researcher (CY) for appropriateness of inclusion into the literature review.  At this stage, articles will be classified as ‘for inclusion’ or ‘excluded’.  The titles and classifications of all articles will be recorded.  Full-texts will be retrieved for any papers in which there is doubt regarding inclusion and these will be read by all researchers and decided by consensus after discussion.  A selection of these abstracts will be read by the second and third researchers (VN, VS).

The full texts of all included articles will be obtained. The full articles will be read by one researcher (CY) to evaluate relevance.  The results of inclusion decisions will be discussed with second and third researchers (VS and VN).  The number of included and excluded papers at each step of the process will be shown through a PRISMA diagram. 

Data collection process and items
The following data will be collected:
a)	Title
b)	Authors
c)	Study aims
d)	Patient population, including ethnicity where available
e)	Inclusion and exclusion criteria
f)	Items required for quality assessment (MMAT) 
CY will collect this data and VS and VN will randomly and independently check a selection of studies to test intercoder agreement.

Quality assessment
Quality of methods will be assessed by one researcher (CY) using the Mixed Methods Appraisal Tool (MMAT).   Any ambiguity will be resolved by discussion with VS and VN.  Appendix 1 outlines the data collection criteria for assessing quality of included studies, with explanations of terms for consistency.

Data synthesis
Drivers for Pacific patient utilisation of Emergency Department or Emergency Room services will be synthesised and evaluated using the qualitative assessment method described by Thomas. 

Dissemination
The results of this analysis will be submitted for publication in a peer-reviewed journal.  Further, CY will present the findings of the research at Counties Manukau District Health Board’s Pacific Health Planning day, which will help inform service delivery planning for this population.

Cultural appropriateness
VN is Associate Professor of Pacific Health.  Further, this research will be supported by extensive senior involvement of Pacific academic and health service professionals who will help ensure that findings are interpreted in a culturally appropriate way that supports positive outcomes for Pacific people.

Ethics
Ethics approval will not be sought as this is a review of published literature.

attributes.title: Penetapan Karantina Wilayah Menurut Pandangan Legal Positivisme Dalam Rangka Pencegahan dan Pemberantasan Pandemi Coronavirus Disease (Covid)-19
attributes.description: Aliran hukum positivism melahirkan pemikiran yang menyatakan bahwa satu-satunya hukum merupakan undang-undang. Aliran positivisme mengedepankan undang-undang tertulis, kaum positivis hukum dengan tegas memisahkan hukum yang ada dengan hukum yang seharusnya ada, pemisahan antara wilayah kontemplatif dan wilayah empiris. Produk hukum seperti Undang-Undang Tentang Kekarantinaan Kesehatan ini merupakan bukti empiris yang selama ini telah dilakukan kajian empiris baik oleh pakar-pakar hukum dan pakar-pakar di bidang kesehatan. Adanya pandemic coronavirus diseas (Covid) 19 menjadikan produk undang-undang dalam UU kekarantinaan kesehatan menjadi penting. Kemampuan virus menyebar dengan cepat dan kemampuannya dalam menimbulkan dampak yang fatal bagi kesehatan menyebabkan karantina kesehatan harus segera dilakukan. Penulis ingin mengkaji permasalahan yang muncul yaitu tentang legal positivsme untuk penerapan UU Nomor 6 Tahun 2018 serta dampak yang ditimbulkan jika asas tersebut tidak dilakukan di tengah pandemic Covid-19 ini. Dari hasil kajian, ditemukan bukti bahwa pemerintah belum menjalankan amanat dalam UU Kekarantinaan Kesehatan dengan tidak melakukan karantina wilayah secara ketat, yang berakibat meluasnya dampak yang ditimbulkan yaitu kasus positif bertambah banyak dan kematian meningkat. Hal ini disebabkan karena kurangnya sarana prasarana dalam memenuhi Alat Pelindung Diri (APD) dan alat-alat medis (pemeriksaan penunjang) termasuk ketersediaan bed isolasi dan ventilator yang sangat terbatas. Pandemi ini juga mengakibatkan terhambatnya roda perekonomian dengan banyaknya sekotr-sektor yang mengalami kerugian. Pemerintah tidak mengupayakan adanya karantina wilayah dikarenakan mempertimbangkan faktor ekonomi serta kemungkinan adanya kekhawatiran jika pemerintah tidak mampu membiayai seluruh masyarakat yang terdampak jika nanti karantina wilayah benar-benar diberlakukan.

attributes.title: A prospective examination of relationships between social media use and body dissatisfaction in a representative adult sample
attributes.description:
Body dissatisfaction is not only associated with negative emotions but also is a risk factor for the development of depressive and anxiety symptoms, poor quality of life, health risk behaviours, disordered eating and clinical eating disorders in males and females (McLean & Paxton, 2019).  Consequently, understanding risk factors that contribute to the development of body dissatisfaction has been a focus of research (e.g., Rodgers, Paxton, & McLean, 2014).  Risk factor research has been guided by a number of theoretical models, but a dominant one is the Tripartite Influence Model (Thompson, Heinberg, Altabe, & Tantleff-Dunn, 1999).  This model emphasises sociocultural risk factors, particularly social environments in which there are high levels of exposure to society’s appearance ideals (i.e., thin for females, and lean and muscular for males) including family, peers and media environments (Rodgers, McLean, & Paxton, 2015).  Of these environments, recent research has examined the potential risk factor role of high levels of exposure to social media, the focus of the present research in which data were collected annually across three years (2016, 2017, 2018) in a large representative community sample of adult New Zealanders.

Exposure to social media has been proposed to be a risk factor for the development of body dissatisfaction for a number of reason (see Tamplin, McLean, & Paxton, 2018).  A combination of peer and media environments, social media is highly visual and content frequently shows idealised images. It is proposed that these images create unrealistic appearance standards that are, for most people, impossible to attain and thus result in negative self-evaluation of one’s own body (Tamplin et al., 2018).  Further the highly interactive nature of social media is likely to add to their negative impact in this regard (McLean, Paxton, Wertheim, & Masters, 2015).
Empirical research provides support for a relationship between greater social media exposure and greater body dissatisfaction.  For example, a meta-analysis of cross-sectional relationships found a significant but small, positive relationship between social media use and body dissatisfaction (Saiphoo, & Vahedi, 2019).  In addition, experimental studies find that exposure to idealised social media images compared to non-appearance social media images have a negative impact on short-term body dissatisfaction (e.g., Tamplin et al., 2018). 

However, these studies do not provide information about the temporal relationship between social media use and body dissatisfaction, for which prospective studies are required.  One prospective study reflects on this issue.  In a study of adolescent girls and boys, De Vries, Peter, de Graaf, and Nikken (2016) found that higher social media use predicted body dissatisfaction up to 18-months later.  However, a major limitation of research in this area is the lack of longitudinal data in adult community samples that allows examination of the temporal relationships between social media use and body image.  Although the Tripartite Influence Model proposes elevated (social) media use will increase risk of future body dissatisfaction, it is also feasible that body dissatisfaction may increase social media use (Saiphoo & Vahedi, 2019), perhaps in an attempt to seek appearance related information to guide self-improvement.  Although prospective relationships in both directions are plausible, previous data do not exist to guide predictions as to the strength of the relationships. Thus, we will compare the strength of proposed relationships in each direction.

We propose to overcome this limitation regarding lack of examination of temporal relationships between social media use and body dissatisfaction in adults by examining data from the large longitudinal study of a representative sample of New Zealand adults, the New Zealand Attitudes and Values Study (NZAVS).  We will examine relationships between self-reported frequency of social media use and body dissatisfaction at three time points, 2016, 2017, 2018. We propose that social media use will predict increases in body dissatisfaction across three time points.

Further, an exploratory aim is to examine the moderating role of gender, age and body mass index (BMI).  There is relatively little data to guide hypotheses regarding moderators. However, we propose that gender will not moderate the relationship between social media use and body image across time, as one systematic review did not find gender moderated cross-sectional relationships between these two variables (Holland & Tiggemann, 2016).  In relation to age, although body dissatisfaction is frequently present in midlife (McLean, Paxton, & Wertheim, 2010), a 20-year follow-up study of college students found body dissatisfaction to be lower in midlife than in college years (Keel, Baxter, Heatherton, & Joiner, 2007).  Thus, there may also be a change in factors that influence body dissatisfaction across age.  In relation to BMI, although higher BMI typically predicts the development of body dissatisfaction (Paxton, Eisenberg, & Neumark-Sztainer, 2006), there has been little examination of BMI as a potential moderator of the influence of social media on body dissatisfaction.  It is feasible that individuals with higher compared with lower BMI would be more negatively affected by the idealised appearance images presented on social media.  We plan to explore this possibility.

Finally, ethnicity, socioeconomic status (SES) and relationship status, have been observed in some research to have an impact on the development of body dissatisfaction (Laus, Almeida & Klos, 2018; Paxton et al., 2006).  However, these variables are not the focus of the present research and so will be controlled for in analyses.

In summary, this study will examine bi-directional prospective relationships between social media use and body dissatisfaction in a large representative sample of New Zealand adults. Analyses will control for SES, ethnicity and relationship status and also examine the moderating role of gender, age, and BMI, predicting that the relationship between social media use and body dissatisfaction will be stronger in younger participants and participants with higher BMI. Gender is not expected to moderate the prospective relationships between social media and body dissatisfaction.

q1.value: Mathew D. Marques, Susan J. Paxton, Siân A. McLean, Hannah K. Jarman, Chris G Sibley

q2.value:
We predict bi-directional positive longitudinal associations between social media use and body dissatisfaction, assessed in a subsequent wave when controlling for body dissatisfaction and social media use in the earlier wave (along with control variables, gender, age, race, relationships status, SES).  

We will explore the effects of several moderators on the prospective relationship between social media use and body dissatisfaction, as well as between body dissatisfaction and social media use. Specifically, we will test the moderating effects of age, gender, and BMI on these relationships.

question.value: The New Zealand Attitudes and Values Study (NZAVS) is a nation-wide study that has been assessing the socio-political attitudes of New Zealanders each year since 2009. People randomly sampled from the New Zealand Electoral Roll received invitations to participate in a mail-based survey. They were posted a copy of the survey, along with a second postal follow-up two months later. Those who provided an email address were also emailed and invited to complete an online version instead (for more information, see www.nzvalues.org). More detailed sampling information can be found in the NZAVS Technical documents relating to sampling procedure and sample details found here https://www.psych.auckland.ac.nz/en/about/our-research/research-groups/new-zealand-attitudes-and-values-study/nzavs-tech-docs.html

q11.value: We intend to use all participants who have complete data for the analyses, using full information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimation to deal with missing values. The sample size is detailed in the "NZAVS-Technical-Documents-e01-Sampling-Procedure-and-Sample-Details.pdf" uploaded here on the project page.

q12.value: Given the healthy size of the NZAVS sample, we expect to have sufficient power to find small effects.

question.value: N/A.

Body Satisfaction

Waves 8, 9, and 10: BodSatT8, BodSatT9, BodSatTJ

Covariates

Gender (GENT8)
Age (AGET8)
Ethnicity (EthEurT8)

Partnered (PartnrT8);


Moderators

Gender (GENT8)
Age (AGET8)
Body Mass Index (BMIT8)

extra.selectedFileName: NZAVS T9 T10 body image syntax for CLPM over two timepoints with moderation.txt

question.value: The coding syntax for all items is attached.

•	We will test a Cross-Lagged Panel Model (CLPM) using MPLUS to assess the effects of Social Media Use at t-1 (Wave 8, 9) on Body Dissatisfaction at t (Wave 9, 10) and vice-versa – Body Dissatisfaction at t-1 on Social Media at t. Initially we will describe the data, including missing values and what was done to account for them. In order to account for potential invariance over measurement occasions, we will test this as a stationary CLPM where autoregressive terms across adjacent pairs of years are constrained to equality (e.g., Social Media Use T9 -> Social Media Use T10 is constrained to equality with Social Media Use T8 -> Social Media Use T9), along with cross-lagged terms across adjacent pairs of years (e.g., Social Media Use T9 -> Body Dissatisfaction T10 is constrained to equality with Social Media Use T8 -> Body Dissatisfaction T9). Then we will test the CLPM, by calculating univariate Wald tests of parameter constraint to assess whether the size of a given set of paths differed significantly from another set of paths. Specifically, we will assess the differences between autoregressive paths, and separately assess differences between the cross-lagged paths. Should Wald tests of parameter constraints be insufficient for model testing, we will use model constraints to test differences between reciprocal, causality, reverse causality, and stability models.
See "NZAVS T8 T9 T10 body image syntax for stationary CLPM over three timepoints.txt"

•	As a further analysis, we will test for moderation. We will explore the effects of age, gender, and BMI on body dissatisfaction and social media use (i.e., in both directions) using a CLPM with only two time-points (T9 and T10). Should the moderation be statistically significant (as determined by a significant path from the interaction term to the outcome variable), we will plot the effects and perform simple slopes tests at one standard deviation above and below the mean to aid in interpretation.
For an example, see "NZAVS T9 T10 body image syntax for CLPM over two timepoints with moderation.txt"

q18.value:
Analyses may use a Maximum Likelihood Robust estimator (which adjusts the standard errors and chi-square statistic for non-normality, Yuan & Bentler, 2000), including Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML) estimation.

References
Yuan, K.H., & Bentler, P.M. (2000). Three likelihood-based methods for mean and covariance structure analysis with nonnormal missing data. Sociological Methodology, 30, 165–200 doi: 10.1111/0081-1750.00078

In the event of extreme violations of normality (as determined by dividing the skewness coefficient by the SE of skewness and using z = 3.29 or z = -3.29 as the criterion, as well as looking at the shape of the curve), we will transform the distribution of any given variable beginning with square root transformations and then progressing to logarithmic and inverse transformations, if necessary.  Given the very large sample size, it may be necessary to retain the original untransformed data if none of the transformations works to alleviate the skew.  In this case, we would examine univariate outliers and winsorize any extreme values of 99.9% (+ 3.29 standard deviations from the mean or more).

q19.value: Analyses will use the conventional p < .05 criteria for NHST.  Given the power to find tiny effects to be significant, we will need to be circumspect about what represents an important effect.  For tests of models, we will be treating SRMR ≤ .08 and RMSEA ≤ .08 as indicators of good fit.

q20.value: We may use Mahalanobis’ Distance to determine multivariate outliers. Specifically, we will use an alpha value of .001, and determine the appropriate critical value of Mahalanobis’ distance based on the number of degrees of freedom. For example, when df = 5, Mahalanobis’ critical value at p = .001 is 20.52. To determine the effect of multivariate analyses, we will first omit them but if the pattern and significance of results does not change, then we will retain them in the final analyses; if the pattern or significance does change, then they will remain omitted in the final analyses.

q21.value: We will use full information maximum likelihood (FIML) estimation to deal with any missing values.

q22.value:
After the initial analyses described above, there are some additional analyses that we would seek to perform, modelled on earlier research. Although we are testing for the moderating effects of age and BMI on both social media use and body dissatisfaction, should we not find evidence of moderation we will consider subgroup analyses to explore differences across age groups and BMI categories using two time points (Waves 9 and 10).
1.	For example, we may explore the bi-directional relationships between social media use and body dissatisfaction in younger (e.g., 18-35 year olds) as compared to those in midlife (e.g., 35-50 year olds; Keel et al., 2007).
2.	We may also explore the bi-directional relationships between social media use and body dissatisfaction across different BMI categories, specifically those in underweight, healthy weight, overweight, and obese categories (World Health Organisation, 2000). 

World Health Organization (WHO) 2000. Obesity: preventing and managing the global epidemic. Report of a WHO consultation. WHO technical report series 894. Geneva: WHO.

1.	For example, we may explore the bi-directional relationships between social media use and body dissatisfaction in younger (e.g., 18-35 year olds) as compared to those in midlife (e.g., 35-50 year olds; Keel et al., 2007).
2.	We may also explore the bi-directional relationships between social media use and body dissatisfaction across different BMI categories, specifically those in underweight, healthy weight, overweight, and obese categories (World Health Organisation, 2000). 

World Health Organization (WHO) 2000. Obesity: preventing and managing the global epidemic. Report of a WHO consultation. WHO technical report series 894. Geneva: WHO.

registration_responses.q10.question: The New Zealand Attitudes and Values Study (NZAVS) is a nation-wide study that has been assessing the socio-political attitudes of New Zealanders each year since 2009. People randomly sampled from the New Zealand Electoral Roll received invitations to participate in a mail-based survey. They were posted a copy of the survey, along with a second postal follow-up two months later. Those who provided an email address were also emailed and invited to complete an online version instead (for more information, see www.nzvalues.org). More detailed sampling information can be found in the NZAVS Technical documents relating to sampling procedure and sample details found here https://www.psych.auckland.ac.nz/en/about/our-research/research-groups/new-zealand-attitudes-and-values-study/nzavs-tech-docs.html

registration_responses.q17.question:
•	We will test a Cross-Lagged Panel Model (CLPM) using MPLUS to assess the effects of Social Media Use at t-1 (Wave 8, 9) on Body Dissatisfaction at t (Wave 9, 10) and vice-versa – Body Dissatisfaction at t-1 on Social Media at t. Initially we will describe the data, including missing values and what was done to account for them. In order to account for potential invariance over measurement occasions, we will test this as a stationary CLPM where autoregressive terms across adjacent pairs of years are constrained to equality (e.g., Social Media Use T9 -> Social Media Use T10 is constrained to equality with Social Media Use T8 -> Social Media Use T9), along with cross-lagged terms across adjacent pairs of years (e.g., Social Media Use T9 -> Body Dissatisfaction T10 is constrained to equality with Social Media Use T8 -> Body Dissatisfaction T9). Then we will test the CLPM, by calculating univariate Wald tests of parameter constraint to assess whether the size of a given set of paths differed significantly from another set of paths. Specifically, we will assess the differences between autoregressive paths, and separately assess differences between the cross-lagged paths. Should Wald tests of parameter constraints be insufficient for model testing, we will use model constraints to test differences between reciprocal, causality, reverse causality, and stability models.
See "NZAVS T8 T9 T10 body image syntax for stationary CLPM over three timepoints.txt"

•	As a further analysis, we will test for moderation. We will explore the effects of age, gender, and BMI on body dissatisfaction and social media use (i.e., in both directions) using a CLPM with only two time-points (T9 and T10). Should the moderation be statistically significant (as determined by a significant path from the interaction term to the outcome variable), we will plot the effects and perform simple slopes tests at one standard deviation above and below the mean to aid in interpretation.
For an example, see "NZAVS T9 T10 body image syntax for CLPM over two timepoints with moderation.txt"

attributes.title: Evidence Mapping: Military Special Operations Performance
attributes.description: Developing an evidence mapping framework to identify and describe the current literature surrounding performance in United States Military Special Operations.

q2.value: Considerable published literature surrounding United States Military Special Operations is available, but has yet to be systematically reviewed and placed into an evidence mapping framework. This systematic review will be the first to quantify and describe the published literature in U.S. Military Special Operations across relevant performance domains.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is an evidence mapping project where the authors will describe and quantify the literature related to performance in US Military Special Operations. This will be done by describing the type of studies (design, population, performance domain, domains measured) and quantifying them as a whole and across performance domains. Qualitative analysis of the studies is beyond the scope of this project.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q9.value: To date, I have only done preliminary literature searches to assess the scope of different search term combinations. I have not yet executed the official literature search, excluded irrelevant literature, pulled any of the full texts, or analyzed any of the data.

question.value:
1. Condition or domain being studied:  Contributors to performance in military special operations 

2. Participants/population: 
- Inclusion: Operators, Male or Female 
- Exclusion: Regular military (unit not under SOCOM), Foreign military

3. Intervention(s), exposure(s): The only required exposure will be activity in US SOF. This will include studies with and without interventions. 

4. Comparator(s)/control: Not applicable.

5. Types of study to be included:
- Inclusion criteria: Observational studies, randomly controlled trials, systematic reviews, narrative reviews, meta-analysis
- Exclusion criteria: Historical commentary

6. Context: Studies related to performance in United States Military Special Operations (units falling under command of United States Special Operations Command (USSOCOM)).

7. Search Terms: (((((((((SOF) AND army)) OR ((SOF) AND military)) OR ((rangers) AND army)) OR ((rangers) AND military)) OR ((special forces) AND army)) OR ((special forces) AND military)) OR ((special operations) AND army)) OR ((special operations) AND military); in the databases: PubMed, Web of Science, and PsychINFO; timespan: all years; language: English.

q11.value: Preliminary searches indicate that the initial search may yield >4,000 texts. The plan is that after exclusion criteria, relevant literature will number <1,000.

q12.value: This is based on all of the published literature in U.S Military Special Operations relevant to physical and operational performance.

q13.value: My data collection will include a maximum number of texts based on the number available at the time the official search is executed. The final number of texts to be analyzed will be a minimum number based upon: removing duplicates, screening titles, abstracts, then full texts.

question.value: N/A

Performance domain of article - Physical, Psychological, Nutritional, Recovery, Technical/Tactical, Equipment, Environment. (If one article may be considered to fall into multiple domains it will be counted with each of the relevant domains).

Study design - observational, randomly controlled trial, narrative review, systematic review, meta-analysis; longitudinal, cross sectional, or case study; with or without blinding, randomization, or crossover.

Context of study - Training or Operations.

Measurement domains reported  - Strength, speed, sleep quantity, reaction time, etc.

Population - Sample size, age, sex.
N/A
For each measure the authors will report summary statistics for the findings as a whole and across each performance domain.

q20.value: All data published will be reported.

q22.value: A gap analysis based on the findings from this study is planned after the completion of this evidence mapping project.

q1.value: Bradley Kennedy, Annie Scudds, Suzanne Stewart

q2.value:
Based on the side-effect effect (SEE) previous research, it is predicted that there will be a significant main effect of side-effect valence on intentionality, with helpful outcomes seen as less intentional than harmful ones. It is also predicted that there will be a significant main effect of side-effect valence on ratings of praise/blame, with helpful outcomes receiving little praise and harmful outcomes receiving lots of blame. 

It is also predicted there will be a non-significant main effect of the sex of the agent on intentionality, with no difference in ratings of intentionality for all side-effects between male and female agents. It is also predicted there will be a a non-significant main effect of the sex of the agent on ratings of praise/blame, with no difference in ratings of praise/blame between male and female agents for all side-effects. 

Finally, it is predicted there will be a significant interaction between side-effect valence and sex. Such that female agents will be judged as having more intention towards harmful side-effects than males, while there will be no difference for helpful side-effects. Similarly, female agents will receive more blame for harmful side-effects compared to male agents, while there will be no difference in ratings of praise for helpful side-effects.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 2x2 Within-subjects design - In each vignette the sex of the agent is manipulated: 'Male' / 'Female'. Furthermore, the side-effect (the unintended outcome) is either 'helping' or 'harming' the recipient.

q7.value: Vignettes will be Latin-squared to produce four lists of vignettes. Participants will be pseudo-randomly allocated to one of the four lists using a routing question about their birth month. Each list will consist of 32 vignettes, randomised by the Qualtrics survey software.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We aim to recruit 100 participants, these will be a combination of University students and the UK general public. 
Payment for participation - General public participants will be offered reimbursement for time as a £2 Amazon voucher (digitally by email). University of Chester Psychology students will be offered 2 participation credits.
Participants will be recruited through online study listings (University of Chester participation system), Social media adverts, discussion boards and through the use of a Facebook Messenger AI Chatbot (https://osf.io/xjz98/). 
Eligibility criteria - Due to the computerised nature of the task and because we cannot make alternative arrangements for them, individuals who have severe visual impairments should avoid participation. We also ask that all participants be either native English speakers or fluent in English. Participants must also be over 18 to participate.

q11.value: At the time of pre-registration the power calculation estimate was based on a preceding experiment within the researchers' programme of research with the same number of items. N=100

question.value: The sex of the agent in the vignette (Male,Female) and the side-effect outcome (Helpful,Harmful).

The dependent variables will be (1) perceived intentionality towards the side-effect of the action and (2) perceived praise/blame for the side effect (praise for helpful side effects and blame for harmful side effects). Individual item responses will be entered into the analysis.

Intentionality will be measured by asking to what extent the character in each vignette intentionally caused the side effect in terms of help or harm (e.g., "To what extent did X intentionally help/harm Y?"), and participant will respond on a seven-point Likert scale for each of 32 items from 0 (Not very) to 6 (Very much). 

Praise/blame will be measured by asking how much praise or blame the character deserves for the side effect occurring (e.g., "How much praise/blame does X deserve for helping/harming Y?"), and participants will respond on a seven-point Likert scale for each of 32 items from 0 (None) to 6 (Lots).

R (r-project.org/) will be used for the analysis. 

Descriptive statistics for number of participants, demographic information, Mean ratings of intention, praise/blame. 

Inferential statistics: Cumulative link mixed model (CLMM) - testing main effects and interactions of Sex and Side-effect valence on (1) ratings of intentionality and (2) ratings of praise/blame.

q20.value: If time to complete the survey is unreasonably short, the data will be excluded. It is expected that the survey will take the average reader somewhere between 15 to 30 minutes to complete. Completion times less than 5 minutes would be unreasonably short.

q21.value: Incomplete submissions may still be used. However, where incomplete submissions provide less than 50% of answers, further participants will be recruited.

attributes.title: Study 3 - Investigating the influence of the agent's sex on the Side-Effect Effect; The RISC Project
attributes.description: An online study conducted with Qualtrics survey software. The aim is to investigate the impact of an agent’s sex on people’s interpretation of their actions and the consequences.

q1.value: Bradley Kennedy, Annie Scudds, Suzanne Stewart

q2.value:
Based on the side-effect effect (SEE) previous research, it is predicted that there will be a significant main effect of side-effect valence on intentionality, with helpful outcomes seen as less intentional than harmful ones. It is also predicted that there will be a significant main effect of side-effect valence on ratings of praise/blame, with helpful outcomes receiving little praise and harmful outcomes receiving lots of blame. 

It is also predicted there will be a non-significant main effect of the sex of the agent on intentionality, with no difference in ratings of intentionality for all side-effects between male and female agents. It is also predicted there will be a a non-significant main effect of the sex of the agent on ratings of praise/blame, with no difference in ratings of praise/blame between male and female agents for all side-effects. 

Finally, it is predicted there will be a significant interaction between side-effect valence and sex. Such that female agents will be judged as having more intention towards harmful side-effects than males, while there will be no difference for helpful side-effects. Similarly, female agents will receive more blame for harmful side-effects compared to male agents, while there will be no difference in ratings of praise for helpful side-effects.

attributes.title: Gabriel Legido's Final Project
attributes.description: Study examining the effects of alcohol advertisements on the desirability to drink alcohol.

q1.value: Gabriel Legido, Clare Conry-Murray, Mackenzie Gillen, Thomas Joseph Harrison

q2.value: The participants who are exposed to ads warning the use of alcohol, will have less desire to drink alcohol. On the contrary, those exposed to alcohol promoting ads will have more desire to want to drink alcohol. Also, men will report having more desire to drink than females do, when both genders are exposed to the same condition of the alcohol promoting ads. In addition, the participants exposed to non-alcohol ads will have more desire to want to drink than those exposed to the ads warning the use of alcohol.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 2(gender) x 3(type of advertisement shown)

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: I will be posting a link to social media, and sending the link through email and texts for participants so they can complete the survey. The survey includes demographics, if the participants are college students, state/country of residence and average number of times going out per week. The survey also includes two between-subjects conditions indicating whether seeing an advertisement reports high or low desirability to drink. Participants will be assigned to groups based on the last digit of their phone number.

q11.value: Ideally, I will have 20 per between- subject group (IV1- gender) and (IV2- advertisement exposed to), accounting for 6 levels for a total of 120 participants. I expect to collect data from 80-120 participants.

q12.value: My professor stated to get 20 per cell for between-subjects effects.

q13.value: I plan to stop collecting data once I receive 20 per cell or 120 total.

question.value:
Advertisements shown- 3 levels
1. Alcohol warning advertisement (Heineken)
2. Alcohol promoting advertisement (Heineken)
3. Non-alcohol advertisement (7-Up)

IV: Gender Identity (male or female or other) 
DV: Desirability to drink alcohol

ANOVA to test for main effect between exposure to alcohol waring advertisements and desire to want to drink alcohol. ANOVA to test for main effect between exposure to alcohol promoting advertisements and desire to want to drink alcohol. ANOVA to test for interaction between exposure to alcohol promoting advertisements and desire to drink alcohol in men and women. ANOVA to test for main effect between exposure to non-alcohol advertisements and desire to drink compared to exposure to alcohol warning advertisements and desire to drink.
